build.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to make something, especially a building or something large
build.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The purpose is to build new houses for local people.
The road took many years to build.
They needed $3 million to build the bridge.
It is the female birds that build the nests.
Developers want to build on the site of the old gasworks.
a row of recently built houses
He’s going to build the children a doll’s house.
build.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to make something develop or form
build.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She had built a reputation as a criminal lawyer.
She’s been busy building her career.
Ross took 20 years to build up his business.
We’re trying to build up a picture of what happened.
build.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if a feeling builds, or if you build it, it increases gradually over a period of time
build.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Tension began to build as they argued more frequently.
In order to build your self-esteem, set yourself targets you can reach.
build.translation[0].note_box[0].section: build
to make a house, road, wall, bridge etc using bricks, stone, wood, or other materials
A new stadium will be built for the Olympics.
construct
to build a building, bridge, machine etc. Construct is more formal than build
The council plans to construct two new schools.
put up something
to build a wall, fence, or building, or put a statue somewhere. Put up is less formal than build
The neighbours have put up a new wooden fence.
erect
to build a wall, fence, or building, especially a public building, or put a statue somewhere
A monument to the Canadian soldiers was erected in Green Park.
throw something up
to build something very quickly
Developers have hastily thrown up family homes in the area.
put together
to make something from its parts, for example a piece of furniture
It took an hour to put the bookcase together.
assemble
to put all the parts of something such as a machine or a piece of furniture together
A line of robots assemble the cars.
build.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the shape and size of someone’s body
build.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: You’re a surprisingly strong swimmer for one of such a slight build.
I wanted a more athletic and muscular build.
build.translation[1].note_box[0].section: He was of medium build and wearing a light-coloured jacket.
She was very strong despite her slender build.
He had the thin build of a long-distance runner.
Simpson was of slight build and shy in character.
The man was described as of stocky build with dark hair.
an eight-year-old boy of sturdy build
These exercises will help you achieve a strong muscular build.
build.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to make or put together large things such as buildings, cars, ships, roads etc
build.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: New offices are being built on the site.
No new ships are being built at the yard now.
Sales of cars built in the US are falling.
build.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to create something over a long period of time by adding to it gradually
build.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: a peasant’s son who built an enormous business empire
He built the company into one of the world’s biggest jewelery concerns.
The drugs company has built up a formidable sales force.
The government has recently built up currency reserves by buying U.S. dollars.
build.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: when lawyers build a case, they put together facts, information etc to try to convince a court that someone is innocent or guilty
build.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: He said prosecutors had built a case based on circumstantial evidence  (=evidence that can make you believe that something happened, but does not prove that it did).
